subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] New to the Quikscript
msgSnippet: Welcome to the group! I have been playing with QS for almost a year, and I have just come to the conclusion, after much wrestling with Read s manual, and
messageBody:
Re: [Read_Alphabet] New to the Quikscript
Welcome to the group!

I have been playing with QS for almost a year, and I have just come to the conclusion, after much wrestling with Read's manual, and arguing with his ideas, that he was right in his approach all along.

Read evolved QS from Shavian (which he also invented)  after a lengthy correspondence with English speakers all over the gobe, and quickly realized that it was hopeless to try and create a feasible communication tool that took into account all the vagaries of English pronunciation.  Therefore, with logic and speed being his utmost goals, he established "rules" for QS spelling.

It is now apparent to me that QS is a series of spelling conventions, designed to make handwriting (and reading) faster, more economical, and - eventually - easier.  It is merely a series of (somewhat) arbitrary rules, just as traditional orthography is, except that it is more rational, and therefore more easily learned.

Of course, you are free to obey the rules or not, depending on how much you will be interacting with other QS writers. Even I can't agree with a few.

Those whose interest tend towards establishing a "standard of pronunciation" however, are more prone to the Yahoo Shavian group, where this debate has been stewing for years.

I have tried to digest most of his conventions from Read's QS manual and arranged them in (perhaps) a more convenient way than he did.  (I see they were not detailed on the Omniglot site.) The results are below.

***************************

The spelling is in Senior QS, using half-letters where called for.

I suggest transfering the text to a spreadsheet, to easily reformat the letters in the "QS" column  to the Jerome font for proper reading,

The "!" indicates the syllable is stressed.

     Hello everyone.  :)  I'm a new to the board; I just discovered
the Read Alphabet the other day on Omniglot.com and I was fascinated
by the idea of using a different script to write English.  I've got
most of the letters down (at least in its "junior" form), but there
are some letters that I'm not sure how to use, and some sounds for
which I'm not sure which letter to use, for instance the common "er"
suffix, as in "maker". 
     Also, I was wondering how users of the alphabet deal with
different pronounciations due to differences in dialect.  Is there
a "standard" Read form for each English word, or would one simply
write the words as his or her dialect pronounces them?
     If these questions have been answered anywhere else on board,
could someone direct me to the thread they're in?  Thanks.
Ryan
